awd_titl_txt: CPS:Small:Collaborative Research: Incentivizing Desirable User Behavior in a Class of CPS
awd_abstract_narration:
In Cyberphysical Systems (CPS) such as large scale infrastructure systems, individual users are shifting from being passive consumers of services to active participants. This shift promises societal, economic, and environmental benefits.  For example, turning consumers into "prosumers" through distributed renewable energy integration can improve sustainability, and turning users into sources of data about traffic and road conditions can help alleviate congestion. However, an explosion of decision makers also leads to heterogeneity in concerns, aims, and quality of decision making. Participants will optimize their decisions on data collection, data sharing, and actuation based on their own self-interest. In an interconnected system, these decisions will affect the system state, and hence, the utilities other participants derive from the system. In extreme cases, undesirable and unintended consequences such as instability can also ensue from actions of a few decision makers.  Thus, there is an urgent need to understand and modulate decision making by various participants so that they internalize the impact on system performance and utilities of the other participants that their decisions produce; the proposed research solves basic problems in this domain.  The proposed research has potentially substantial social and economic impact. The general trend in CPS systems, such as infrastructure systems, is to allow users to become active participants. However, this will challenge the traditional algorithms and organization for such systems. Since most CPS systems provide basic services to the population, designs that guarantee reliable operation in spite of strategic behavior of self-interested participants are needed.  The research is coupled with an education plan that includes integration of research and education, curriculum design, student advising and training, as well as outreach.

Existing approaches such as cooperative control or competitive game theory in which participants are price takers are insufficient to consider strategic behavior by participants. Motivated by this observation, this proposal will advance the science of CPS by (i) abstracting this problem into one of designing contracts by which the decisions of strategic users, who may anticipate the effect of their actions and misreport any information, can be aligned to obtain desired system performance, (ii) presenting new mechanisms for this model under several assumptions inspired by large scale CPS such as smart infrastructure systems, and (iii) demonstrating the efficacy of this framework by applying it to several CPS case studies. The proposed approach couples optimization and systems theory with economics and mechanism design as well as models and constraints from specific infrastructure systems.

por.por_cntn:
This proposal considered the design of incentives to induce desirable behavior by active participants in a class of large-scale, distributed CPS systems such as smart infrastructure systems. The project led to many advances as summarized briefly below: 

1.    Contracts for reliability in power grid: A major direction was on the design of market mechanisms for integration of renewable sources in the power grid. In today's grid-takes-all-renewable scenario, intermittent nature of renewable energy increases operation costs of conventional generators leading to market frictions. We showed that a higher penetration of renewable energies may increase the consumer price of energy. To cap the consumer price, the cost of providing reliability can be imposed either on conventional generators (by compensating them only for the energy they sell and not the energy they commit) -- leading to market frictions -- or on renewables (through a penalty if the renewable player is unable to meet its commitment) leading to low commitment by renewables. Instead, we designed contracts between renewable and conventional generators that can provide reliable low-cost energy to consumers, while increasing profits for both types of generators. We also showed that such reliability contracts can also be written between RPPs and storage owners. This is particularly interesting since such contracts provide an extra source of revenue for storage owners that may not be profitable with a purely arbitrage based strategy in the day-ahead market.

2.    Contracts for crowdsensing: Crowdsensing has been proposed in a variety of contexts. A system operator hires sensors to exert costly effort to collect accurate measurements of a value of interest. Since both the effort and the observation are private information for the sensor, a naive payment scheme which compensates the sensor based only on its self-reported values of the effort and the measurements will lead to both shirking and falsification of reported outcomes by the sensor. First, in a one-shot setting, we proposed an incentive mechanism which ensures that all the sensors exerting maximum effort and reporting truthfully is a game-theoretic equilibrium. Then, in a repeated setting, we proposed a compensation scheme that employs stochastic verification by the operator coupled with an algorithm to assign a reputation to each sensor.  Finally, we considered a setup in which some sensors may be adversarial in that their utility increases with the Euclidean distance between the estimate of the central estimator and their own local estimate. We showed that the estimate at the central estimator may be better than if the measurements from the adversarial sensors were ignored.

3.    Data driven contract design: The third direction was that of data driven contract design to understand the role of repeated interactions among the principal and the agents. Consider a game in which a principal seeks to incentivize an agent to exert effort that is costly to the agent. The amount of effort exerted by the agent and her cost function are private information for the agent and can be misreported to gain higher payment. We showed that if the principal and agent interact only finitely many times, it is always possible for the agent to lie due to the asymmetric information pattern and claim a higher payment. However, if the principal and agent interact infinitely many times, then the principal can utilize the observed outcomes to update the contract so that the agent is not able to derive any rent. We also allowed the possibility of collusion among agents explicitly. For a duopoly in which agents are coupled in their payments, we showed that if the principal and the agents interact finitely many times, the agents can derive rent by colluding even if the principal knows the types of the agents. 

4.    Another direction was in consumer-preferred community level energy management system. We considered several avenues. In the first one, we considered a community-level energy management system (CEMS), in which a system manager allows consumers their selfish decisions of power-saving while regulating the overall demand-supply imbalance. We designed an approach to weakly control consumers: the controller sends the allowable range of the power-saving amount to each consumer, which is modeled by a set-valued control signal. Then, the consumers decide the amount in the range based on their private preference. Another avenue was to identify the role of network constraints in contract design. Many counter-intuitive results that cannot be observed in network-free formulations commonly adopted in game-theoretic works on demand-side management followed. Finally, we considered risk based contracts for pricing demand side flexibility to formalize the notion that users in a smart infrastructure system may only be boundedly rational and hence may not be able to correctly identify the risk they are bearing (even though they care about volatility). 

6.    A new class on Game Theory for Electrical Engineers was designed and regularly taught to expose senior undergraduate engineering students to this interdisciplinary area.
